Award.AbstractNarration:
The Organic and Macromolecular Chemistry Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation supports Professor Charles M. Drain of the City University of New York (CUNY) Hunter College for a research project that will continue pushing the limits of self-assembly and self-organization to create functional photonic materials and prototypical devices that contain various porphyrinoids and other highly stable dyes. Porphyrinoids such as porphyrins, phthalocyanines, and porphyrazines are a class of remarkably robust dyes that have a broad range of chemical, physical, and photonic properties. The range of properties is significantly expanded by the binding of metal ions and by peripheral substitution. One of the goals of the research is to understand fundamental principles of supramolecular chemistry related to the hierarchical organization of molecules and atoms. Conceptually, there are four levels describing the organization of matter: (1) molecular structure, (2) supramolecular structure, (3) self-organization into solid-state materials and (4) self-organization of these materials onto surfaces in devices, which includes interconnections to the macroscopic world. The correlation of hierarchical structure with photonic properties will lead to new design principles and materials with enhanced functions. These results will lead to a better understanding of hierarchical organization in natural systems, and provide a roadmap to the construction of other complex self-organized materials with designed functionality. The systematic comparison of the photonic properties of component molecules, discrete self-assembled arrays and self-organized materials, is an explicit part of the proposal. Though every supramolecular design may not result in the predicted structures, unexpected results can be very informative in terms of understanding intermolecular interactions and the response of these materials to environment changes and deposition onto surfaces. The results of the proposed research will significantly increase the repertoire of self-assembly/organization concepts that underpin the design of hierarchical functional materials for an array of applications beyond photonic materials.

Broader impacts of the proposed research include the training of a diverse population of students. Because of Professor Drain's vigorous, proactive recruiting of a diverse population of students, his lab consists of approximately 50% women and 50% minorities in STEM areas. Former minority undergraduates are now in Ph.D. programs or have graduated from universities such as Rockefeller, Berkeley, Columbia, and Cornell. Thus, the education and training of women and underrepresented minorities in STEM continues to be a hallmark of Professor Drain's research program. A new Analytical chemistry lab at Hunter College is proposed (30-40 majors per year will take the course) that will focus on state of the art instrumentation and assays that are specifically derived from the prior NSF-sponsored research on porphyrin materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported research at Hunter College of the City University of New York, in the laboratory of Charles Michael Drain. The scientific outcomes include the development of new methods to synthesize commercially viable, multifunctional, photonic materials that contain different dyes. These photonic materials convert visible light into chemical energy for catalysts and therapeutics, or electrochemical energy for solar energy harvesting. The function of the materials depends both on the structure of the dye molecule, for example what wavelengths of light it absorbs, and on how the dyes are organized in the material, for example face-to-face aggregates versus side-to-side aggregates. The goal is to bring the synthetic costs of the materials in line with potential commercialization, by using molecules that are designed to self-assemble into the structures needed for these applications. The intellectual merit lies in the development and dissemination of:  new molecular design principles, new synthetic methods to make the dyes, new materials, and assessments of the materials properties. There are now many researchers building upon these results and on company, Huhu Technology, sell some of the core dye platforms. The specific outcomes are described in over 15 publications and include the following. (1) We developed the chemistry and assessment of the photo physical properties of five new dyes for the targeted treatment of cancers using the dye and light as next generation photodynamic therapeutics. These have cancer targeting sugars attached. (2) We developed the chemistry of new dyes for solar energy harvesting and assessed the device efficiencies. These tune the wavelength of light absorbed to collect more of the sunlight and are designed for applications on windows in urban settings. (3) We developed several new strategies to assemble different molecules into photonic materials. To make organic solar energy materials feasible, the cost of the material must not be prohibitively high. Self-assembly is one way to significantly bring the costs of these materials down.

The broader impacts, beyond contributing to the science and technology of photonic materials, are as follows. The success of most arenas in academic, industrial, and government institutions will increasingly depend on a well-trained science workforce for innovation, planning, and policy. Since economic development correlates with scientific innovation, many view scientific education and science literacy of the stakeholders to be a critical issue facing the nation. (1) This project contributed significantly to the education, training, and mentoring of student in science, technology and chemistry. It supported the research of six Ph.D. students and four undergraduates. Of these, four are from underrepresented or disadvantaged backgrounds. Three of the doctoral students are now on the faculty of universities and three of the undergraduates are now in doctoral programs in chemistry. One undergraduate started a company. (2) Getting students at all educational levels meaningfully involved in a collaborative research program enhances everyone’s perspectives in science, fosters collegiality and mentorship, and drives innovation. My observations are that focusing on one part of the pipeline, e.g. K-12 or undergraduate students, diminishes the recruiting potential, unique perspectives, and capacity for peer mentorship. This project supported collaborative teams that foster persistence in science in general and chemistry in particular.
